header.title: La Mystique Divine, Naturelle et Diabolique, Tome V: La Mystique Diabolique
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Demonology, History of Magic

central_thesis: This volume meticulously documents the historical understanding of diabolical mystique, analyzing how individuals engaged with infernal powers through voluntary pacts or inherent dispositions, leading to demonic possession, spiritual corruption, and participation in blasphemous rituals like the Witches' Sabbath. It further explores the societal impact, legal responses, and theological interpretations of these phenomena across various European regions from the medieval period through the 17th century.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre Premier: Comment l'homme passe de la possession à l'union volontaire avec le démon. Pierre Bernardi.
structure_content.summary: This chapter introduces the concept of voluntary union with demons, distinct from involuntary possession. It presents the case of Pierre Bernardi, illustrating how a demon can be bound by a charm and how the possessed may, through despair or pride, eventually submit to demonic will, becoming instruments of evil.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre II: Origine de la magie diabolique. De la doctrine des Manichéens.
structure_content.summary: The author traces the philosophical origins of diabolical magic to Manichaeism, a doctrine positing two co-eternal, consubstantial principles of good and evil (God of Light and God of Darkness/Lucifer). This dualistic worldview, which attributes matter and sin to the evil principle, provides a theological justification for embracing the demon, setting the stage for human engagement with infernal powers.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre III: Légende racontée par Césaire. Histoire racontée par Brognoli. Psellus.
structure_content.summary: This section examines historical accounts and legends of heretics and magicians performing 'false miracles' with demonic assistance, often aimed at deceiving the populace. It highlights the perceived power of these diabolical acts and their limitations, particularly when confronted with divine symbols or sacred objects like the cross and consecrated host.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre IV: Influence du judaïsme sur la magie. Le Talmud et la Cabale.
structure_content.summary: The chapter explores the influence of Jewish mystical traditions, specifically the Talmud and Cabala, on the understanding of magic and demonology. It details the hierarchy of infernal spirits (Smaël, Lilith), their destructive aims, and the belief in their ability to acquire power over humans, notably through blood and offerings.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre V: Influence des Bohémiens. Leur origine; leurs migrations; leur caractère. La chiromancie.
structure_content.summary: This chapter investigates the role of the Romani (Bohemian) people in the transmission and popularization of magical practices, particularly chiromancy. It describes their perceived nomadic lifestyle, moral indifference, and their ability to impress and deceive by adapting existing magical knowledge and superstitions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre VI: Dispositions naturelles à la magie et à la sorcellerie. L'Église cherche à les détruire. Saint Taurin.
structure_content.summary: The author discusses natural predispositions to magic and sorcery, influenced by temperament and astral forces, and rooted in lingering pagan beliefs about nature deities (e.g., Diana/Hecate, Lamia). The Church's efforts to combat these 'false' divinities, reinterpreting them as demons, are presented, with Saint Taurin's actions as a key example.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre VII: Des influences locales de la magie. Les Alpes et les Pyrénées.
structure_content.summary: This section localizes the prevalence of magic and sorcery, noting its strong roots in regions like the French Alps and Pyrenees, and Lorraine, where paganism persisted longer or where Manichaean heresies found fertile ground. It suggests a correlation between geographical isolation and the endurance of diabolical practices.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre VIII: Des dispositions individuelles à la magie et de leur développement interne. Histoire arrivée en Danemark.
structure_content.summary: The chapter delves into how individual psychological and physiological states can render a person susceptible to magical influences. The 'Koge case' in Denmark illustrates domestic hauntings and poltergeist activity attributed to a demon, emphasizing how a deep-seated mental disposition can manifest in extraordinary physical phenomena.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre IX: Des lutins et des farfadets. Histoires racontées par Coleti, par Menghi.
structure_content.summary: This chapter describes interactions with minor, mischievous spirits (lutins, farfadets). While seemingly innocent at first, these encounters are warned to be deceptive, often leading to deeper, more serious relationships and formal pacts with demons. Cases from Coleti and Menghi illustrate the progression from playful annoyances to dangerous demonic familiarities.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre X: Des exercices préparatoires à la magie. Les prophètes du Dauphiné.
structure_content.summary: This section details the ascetic practices and rituals believed to prepare individuals for magical powers, particularly among the 'prophets of Dauphiné.' These included severe fasting, scriptural readings (especially the Apocalypse), and inducing somnambulistic states to receive prophetic visions, often in service of anti-Christian movements.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XI: L'action de Satan cachée sous le masque de la sainteté. Madeleine de la Croix.
structure_content.summary: This chapter explores the deceptive nature of Satan, who can appear under the guise of sanctity to ensnare individuals. The case of Madeleine de la Croix, a Franciscan abbess, illustrates how false visions, manufactured miracles, and a hidden demonic pact can lead to profound spiritual corruption while maintaining an outward appearance of holiness.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XII: États personnels de ceux qui sont engagés dans la magie et la sorcellerie. Histoire de Jeanne Fery.
structure_content.summary: The chapter focuses on the internal transformation of individuals who enter a diabolical pact, detailing their renunciation of faith, moral perversion, and physical torment. Jeanne Fery's confession describes her lifelong enslavement to a demon, her participation in sacrilegious acts, and the physical marks left by demonic influence.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XIII: États particuliers de la vie organique dans la magie et la sorcellerie. L'onguent des sorcières.
structure_content.summary: This section examines the physiological dimension of magic, specifically the use of unguents (ointments) and potions by sorcerers. These substances, often derived from narcotic plants or children's fat, were believed to induce magnetic sleep or clairvoyance, facilitating astral travel to the Sabbath and other magical operations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XIV: Des signes extérieurs qui distinguent les sorciers. Ils sont comme le revers des stigmates.
structure_content.summary: The chapter discusses the physical marks (stigmates diaboliques) found on sorcerers' bodies, such as insensitive spots, abnormal growths, or discolorations. These are interpreted as outward signs of their demonic pacts and inner corruption, a blasphemous inversion of divine stigmata.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XV: Le sabbat considéré comme orgie. Des repas et des voluptés du sabbat.
structure_content.summary: The Witches' Sabbath is portrayed as a monstrous orgiastic feast, a diabolical parody of the Eucharist. Participants consume putrefied human flesh (especially unbaptized children) and engage in sexual promiscuity, solidifying their bond with the demon who presides over these rituals.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XVI: De la physionomie et de l'odeur infecte des sorcières.
structure_content.summary: This chapter describes the physical degeneration and foul, repulsive odor (foetiditas) attributed to sorcerers and witches. These characteristics are presented as outward manifestations of their internal spiritual corruption, their pact with the demon, and the destructive nature of their practices.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XVII: États personnels de la partie psychique de l'homme dans la sorcellerie. Voyage mystérieux des sorcières.
structure_content.summary: The chapter discusses the 'mysterious voyages' of sorcerers to the Sabbath, often involving out-of-body experiences or astral projection while their physical bodies remain inert. It attributes this ability to the demon's influence, enabling them to 'fly' over vast distances and participate in collective demonic assemblies.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XVIII: Le sabbat considéré comme la cour du démon.
structure_content.summary: This section describes the Witches' Sabbath as a formal court of the demon, detailing its typical locations (mountains, desolate places, sometimes even churches), frequencies (Thursdays, Fridays, Saturdays nights), and the monstrous forms assumed by demons (e.g., goat, long black man) during these gatherings. It highlights the blasphemous imitation of ecclesiastical structures.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XIX: De l'hommage que les sorciers rendent au démon dans le sabbat. Despotisme du démon.
structure_content.summary: This chapter details the acts of homage performed by sorcerers at the Sabbath, including kissing the demon's hindquarters, symbolizing their absolute servitude. It contrasts the demon's false promises of wealth and power with the actual misery and degradation experienced by his followers, illustrating the despotic nature of demonic rule.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XX: Effets de la magie dans l'intelligence. De quelle manière les initiés sont reçus dans la cité du diable.
structure_content.summary: The chapter examines the intellectual and spiritual corruption of initiates into diabolical magic. It describes the blasphemous rites of initiation, including renunciation of God, Christ, and sacraments, and false baptisms. Children are often presented to the demon for consecration, marking them as future servants.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XXI: Le sabbat considéré comme église des initiés. Les sacrifices. La messe. Le culte du sabbat.
structure_content.summary: This section further details the Sabbath as a diabolical church, complete with its own blasphemous liturgy. It describes anti-sacraments such as consuming wine consecrated with maledictions and bread made from peas, symbolizing a complete inversion of Christian rites and a deeper union with the principle of destruction and death.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XXII: Le sabbat des clercs. Madeleine Bavent. Liturgie du sabbat.
structure_content.summary: This chapter focuses on the involvement of clergy in diabolical practices. It discusses the concept of 'Sabbats des clercs' and uses Madeleine Bavent's testimony to illustrate how priests performed blasphemous masses using consecrated hosts, which would appear discolored or bleeding, symbolizing profound sacrilege and corruption.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XXIII: Rapports spirituels produits par la magie. Mystagogues de la magie.
structure_content.summary: This section describes the spiritual rapport forged through magic, where practitioners become 'mystagogues of hell.' It highlights how figures like David, Picard, and Boullé, through deceptive doctrines and sensual temptations, corrupted religious women, establishing an 'invisible church' of the infernal realm, characterized by a diabolical 'marriage' with demons.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XXIV: L'abus des sacrements considéré comme moyen magique. Marguerite du Saint-Sacrement.
structure_content.summary: The chapter explains how the abuse and profanation of holy sacraments, especially the Eucharist, were perceived as potent magical acts in diabolical mystique, diverting divine power for evil ends. The case of Marguerite du Saint-Sacrement illustrates how her body reacted with violent convulsions and horror upon approaching sacred objects, due to the demons' influence.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XXV: De l'obsession spirituelle. La sœur Saint-Michel. La sœur Anne de la Nativité.
structure_content.summary: This chapter details spiritual obsession, where demons torment individuals through visions, physical phenomena, and blasphemous thoughts, aiming to bind their will. Cases like Sister Barbe de Saint-Michel and Anne de la Nativité demonstrate how demons appear in various forms, cause poltergeist activity, and influence the possessed to act against their faith.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XXVI: Rapports psychiques dans l'obsession. Les religieuses d'Auxonne; celles du Saint-Esprit, à Louviers.
structure_content.summary: This section explores the psychological dimensions of obsession, often manifesting as contagious epidemics in convents. It describes how nuns in Auxonne and Louviers exhibited symptoms like speaking in unknown languages (xenoglossia), clairvoyance of distant events, and insensitivity to pain, all attributed to demonic influence and suggesting a collective hysterical or possessed state.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XXVII: De la contagion psychique dans la possession. Elle attaque surtout les jeunes gens. Les enfants d'Elfdale.
structure_content.summary: The chapter examines the contagious nature of demonic possession, which spreads through a 'psychic miasma' or aura, particularly affecting young, predisposed individuals. Cases like the children of Elfdale and Amsterdam are cited, where children experienced transport to the Sabbath and bore physical marks from demonic beatings.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XXVIII: Passage de l'obssession à la possession par l'épidémie démoniaque. Les religieuses de Quercy; celles de Kentorp; celles de Werte.
structure_content.summary: This section details the escalation from obsession to full possession in epidemic contexts, especially among nuns. Cases from Quercy, Kentorp, and Werte illustrate how large groups of religious women displayed animalistic behaviors, clairvoyance, and physical contortions, often facilitated by a 'mediator' who initiated the demonic influence.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XXIX: Rapports vitaux de l'homme avec le démon. Possession de l'instinct de nutrition.
structure_content.summary: This chapter explores how demons possess and manipulate basic human instincts, focusing on nutrition. It describes individuals experiencing abnormal cravings, ingesting strange objects (pins, glass, hair), and vomiting animals, as seen in cases like the young man in Amsterdam and Marie de Mœrl, where the demon targeted the digestive organs.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XXX: L'avarice considérée comme établissant des rapports intimes entre l'homme et les métaux. Gertrude Fischer.
structure_content.summary: This chapter links the vice of avarice to a magnetic rapport between humans and metals, which demons exploit. The case of Gertrude Fischer, who swallowed gold and silver, illustrates how demonic influence can induce extraordinary physical phenomena tied to material desires, leading to internal torment and the 'vomiting' of metals.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XXXI: Des rapports de l'instinct dans l'homme avec le règne animal. Histoire d'un enfant.
structure_content.summary: The chapter details how demonic possession can manifest as an alteration of human instincts towards the animal kingdom, often through visions or actual infestations. The story of a boy vomiting various small creatures (frogs, spiders, squirrels, centipedes, beetles) illustrates this phenomenon, suggesting a diabolical metempsychosis affecting the human body and spirit.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XXXII: L'appétit sexuel et la cruauté dans leurs rapports avec la possession. Des incubes et des succubes.
structure_content.summary: This section examines the demon's influence over sexual desire and cruelty, primarily through incubi and succubi. Cases from Bergame and Mabertha describe nightly visitations by demons in attractive forms, leading to sexual acts, spiritual corruption, blasphemy, and the inability to resist their influence.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XXXIII: Des philtres naturels et diaboliques. Histoire d'un jeune homme de Gênes; de Marie Ranfain.
structure_content.summary: The chapter discusses the use of natural and diabolical philtres (potions) to manipulate human passions, particularly love and desire. These concoctions are believed to cause extreme physical and psychological effects, leading to violent passions or strange ailments, often attributed to demonic intervention rather than natural causes, as seen in the cases of a young man from Genoa and Marie Ranfain.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XXXIV: La soif diabolique du sang. La comtesse de Brinvilliers. Le maréchal de Retz. Marie de Sains.
structure_content.summary: This chapter explores the diabolical thirst for blood and extreme cruelty, often leading to infanticide and ritualistic murders as sacrifices to demons. The notorious cases of the Comtesse de Brinvilliers and Maréchal de Retz illustrate these crimes, emphasizing the profound moral depravity and violent desires believed to be instilled by demonic influence.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XXXV: Métamorphoses diaboliques. Les loups-garous. Jean Grenier.
structure_content.summary: This section describes diabolical metamorphoses, particularly lycanthropy (werewolves). Cases like Pierre Bourget and Jean Grenier detail individuals who, through pacts and unguents, believed they transformed into wolves, committing acts of violence and cannibalism, especially against children. These transformations are interpreted as either real or as powerful demonic illusions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XXXVI: Comment la vie possédée par le démon devient un principe de contagion ou un antidote. Le fameux guérisseur Greatrak.
structure_content.summary: The chapter explores the dual nature of demonic influence: as a source of contagion spreading illness and perversion, or as a paradoxical source of healing, as exemplified by Valentin Greatrak. This section suggests that certain individuals possess natural magnetic virtues that can counteract diabolical effects, leading to seemingly miraculous cures through touch or prayer.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XXXVII: Du pouvoir que les magiciens exercent sur les puissances de la nature. Procès singulier sous le roi Jacques d'Écosse.
structure_content.summary: This chapter addresses the power attributed to magicians over natural forces, particularly weather manipulation. The Scottish witch trials under King James VI are presented, where witches were accused of raising storms to harm the king, illustrating the belief in the demon's capacity to influence the elements through human agents.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XXXVIII: Des procès de sorcellerie. De leur base historique.
structure_content.summary: This chapter provides a historical and theological framework for witch trials, linking their prevalence to the spread of Manichaean heresies and societal crises. It discusses the role of the Inquisition in combating diabolical magic, emphasizing the evolving legal and ecclesiastical responses to accusations of sorcery.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XXXIX: Triple problème pour le médecin, le légiste et le théologien.
structure_content.summary: This chapter highlights the complex interdisciplinary challenge of discerning genuine demonic influence from natural illness or psychological delusion in cases of possession and sorcery. It calls for collaboration among physicians, legal scholars, and theologians to navigate these 'transcendent symptoms' and establish just procedures.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XL: De la manière dont on procédait dans les procès de sorcellerie. Des preuves admises dans ces procès. L'accord des témoins. Des paroxysmes qu'éprouvent ceux sur qui l'on a jeté un sort à la vue de celui qui le leur a donné. Faits qui se sont passés en ce genre dans la Nouvelle-Angleterre. Des signes qu'on aperçoit sur le corps des sorcières. L'épreuve de l'eau froide. La torture.
structure_content.summary: This extensive chapter details the procedures and evidentiary standards of witch trials, including the controversial use of torture, the weight given to witness testimonies (even from accomplices), and physical examinations for 'witch marks.' It critically analyzes the reliability of these methods and highlights cases from New England and Europe where miscarriages of justice occurred.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XLI: Des moyens d'une bonne procédure. Procès de Jean de Vaulx.
structure_content.summary: This chapter offers an example of what the author considers a 'good procedure' in witch trials, through the case of Jean de Vaulx. It emphasizes meticulous interrogation, careful assessment of testimony, and judicial discernment to distinguish between demonic influence and delusion, leading to a more moderate sentence than often seen in other cases.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XLII: Des erreurs qui se sont glissées dans le cours des procédures.
structure_content.summary: The chapter critiques the common errors in witch trial procedures, such as judges' credulity towards spectral evidence, the misinterpretation of visions as objective reality, and the reliance on forced confessions. It argues that these errors often stemmed from an incomplete understanding of natural phenomena and demonic deception.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XLIII: Des procès de sorcellerie pendant et après la réformation, en Angleterre, en France, en Allemagne. Histoire de M. de Palud; de Louise Capelle, au couvent de Sainte-Baume. Histoire de trois religieuses dans les Pays-Bas. Critique de ces faits. Histoire arrivée à Louviers.
structure_content.summary: This chapter surveys witch trials across Europe during and after the Reformation, noting regional variations and the socio-political contexts that fueled them. It covers cases like Madeleine de Palud and Louise Capelle, and the notorious Loudun possessions, highlighting how religious conflicts and societal upheaval intensified persecutions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XLIV: Histoire des possédées de Loudun.
structure_content.summary: This chapter provides a detailed account of the infamous Loudun possessions, focusing on Urbain Grandier and the Ursuline nuns. It describes the dramatic manifestations of demonic possession, the public exorcisms, the accusations against Grandier, and the interplay of religious fervor, political intrigue, and mass hysteria.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XLV: Des procès de sorcellerie en Angleterre, en Allemagne, pendant et après la guerre de Trente ans. Le jésuite Spée appelle le premier l'attention sur les horreurs de ces procès; il est suivi du protestant Meyfart. Les procès de sorcellerie cessent.
structure_content.summary: This chapter examines the height of witch trials in England and Germany, particularly during the Thirty Years' War, and the subsequent decline of persecutions. It highlights the work of figures like Jesuit Friedrich Spee and Protestant Johann Meyfart, who critically analyzed the trials, exposing their injustices and contributing to their eventual cessation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XLVI: L'Église dans ses rapports avec les procès de sorcellerie. Instruction de la chambre apostolique à Rome. Conduite du P. Surin.
structure_content.summary: This chapter delineates the evolving stance of the Catholic Church regarding witch trials, contrasting the often brutal secular procedures with Rome's instructions for moderation and discernment. It cites the P. Surin's approach to the Loudun possessions as an example of a more compassionate and theologically grounded method, emphasizing spiritual combat over physical coercion.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapitre XLVII: Épilogue du traducteur.
structure_content.summary: The translator's concluding remarks synthesize the preceding analysis, affirming the enduring reality of mystical phenomena (both divine and diabolical) throughout history. It stresses the continuous struggle between good and evil, the deceptive nature of demons, and the importance of spiritual discernment, caution, and faith in navigating these complex phenomena.

key_concepts.definition: A historical concept describing the spiritual and physical phenomena resulting from an individual's voluntary or involuntary engagement with infernal powers, often involving pacts and leading to possession and corruption.

A state where an individual's body and soul are directly controlled by a demon, manifesting through abnormal physical acts, speech in unknown tongues, clairvoyance, and blasphemies. It is often preceded by obsession and can be contagious.

An initial stage of demonic influence where a demon binds the individual's will, tormenting them with visions, internal struggles, and impulses to commit sin. It can escalate to full possession and is often linked to psychological or moral predispositions.

A nocturnal assembly where sorcerers and witches gather to pay homage to the demon (often in the form of a goat or monstrous man), engage in blasphemous rites, orgiastic feasts, and sacrifices, including the consumption of unbaptized children. It is understood as a diabolical inversion of Christian rituals.
A harmful magical act or charm, often involving concoctions, inscribed amulets, or specific rituals, believed to inflict illness, misfortune, or death upon others through demonic agency.

A dualistic religious doctrine, fundamental to the origin of diabolical magic as understood in this text, which posits two co-eternal principles of light and darkness. It attributes matter and evil deeds to the evil principle, providing a theological justification for embracing demonic forces.

Demonic entities that engage in sexual intercourse with humans during sleep. Incubi are male demons who lie with women, and succubi are female demons who lie with men, leading to physical and spiritual corruption, and often blasphemous acts.

A form of heightened perception, often induced by narcotic substances or ecstatic states, allowing individuals to perceive hidden objects, distant events, or the infernal realm itself. This is distinct from divine clairvoyance and is always linked to demonic influence.

Physical marks or insensibilities on the body of sorcerers and witches, such as small elevations, red or black spots, or areas immune to pain or bleeding. These are believed to be the demon's seal, marking them as his servants and symbolizing their pact and inner corruption.

Magical drinks or unguents used to influence passions, particularly sexual desire. These are often made from narcotic herbs, animal fats (e.g., children's fat), or other sinister ingredients, believed to induce trance states, cause illness, or manipulate affections through demonic power.

The phenomenon by which demonic possession or obsession can spread epidemically among groups, often in convents or communities. It is described as a 'miasma' or 'aura' that affects psychologically or morally predisposed individuals, leading to shared symptoms and behaviors.

The belief that sorcerers, through a pact with the demon and the use of special unguents, could transform into animals (e.g., werewolves) or take on animalistic traits. These transformations are often seen as either literal physical changes or powerful demonic illusions affecting perception.

practical_system.description: As a historical analysis rather than a modern practical manual, this book describes the *operative principles and methods* attributed to diabolical magic and possession in various historical accounts. The 'system' is therefore the historical understanding of how individuals (sorcerers, witches, possessed) interacted with demons and achieved their 'magical' effects, as believed and documented at the time. This system operates on a dualistic worldview, where individuals intentionally or unintentionally open themselves to infernal powers, exchanging spiritual well-being for worldly desires or perceived abilities.
tools: Amulets: Wax figures with written signs, letters, and words (e.g., Gog and Magog, tetragrammaton, Adonaï and Sabaoth) placed under doors to bind demons or for other magical effects (p. 12, 14, 260).

Unguents: Ointments made from children's fat or narcotic plants (e.g., satyrium) used to induce ecstatic states, facilitate astral travel to the Sabbath, or achieve metamorphosis (pp. 171, 194, 359-360, 390).

Potions (Philtres): Drinks (e.g., in beer) or concoctions (e.g., from children's ashes, various herbs) to cause specific ailments, induce violent passions, or poison enemies (pp. 212, 359, 370-371, 374).
Symbolic objects: Items like cords, hair, bones, or pieces of clothing used in charms or as pledges in pacts (pp. 13, 230).
Magical circles: Traced on the ground with an épée or chalk to conjure and contain spirits (pp. 30, 323).
Inscribed papers/books: Documents detailing pacts, blasphemies, or magical formulas (pp. 147-148, 228, 232).
rituals: Voluntary pacts with demons: Written in blood, involving renunciation of God, Christ, and Christian sacraments. This grants demons power over the individual's soul and body (pp. 147-148).
Blasphemous anti-sacraments at the Sabbath: Consuming putrefied human flesh (especially unbaptized children) and wine consecrated with maledictions, parodying the Eucharist (pp. 179-180, 231-232).
Acts of homage to the demon: Kissing the demon's hindquarters, symbolizing absolute servitude and profanation (p. 218).
Diabolical baptisms: Using sulfur, salt, and urine, replacing Christian names with new diabolical ones (p. 252).
Orgiastic dances and communal promiscuity: Performed at the Sabbath to solidify the bond with demons and among adepts (pp. 187, 222-223).
Sacrifices: Offering children, blood, and other valuable items to demons as recognition of their power (pp. 180-181, 219, 380-381).
Reciting diabolical litanies and prayers: Inverting Christian prayers to invoke demons and their powers (p. 245).

D'après l'analyse que Psellus, vers la fin du xie siècle, a faite de la doctrine des Manichéens, telle qu'elle existait chez les Euchites ou Enthousiastes, secte manichéenne qui existait dans la Thrace, ceux-ci admettaient comme principes un père et deux fils. Le père gouverne le monde supérieur, et les fils président, le plus jeune au monde céleste, et l'aîné au monde inférieur. Conformément à cette division fondamentale, ils partageaient tout en trois. Quelques-uns rendaient les honneurs divins aux deux fils en même temps, parce que, quoiqu'ils ne fussent pas toujours d'accord ensemble, ils étaient néanmoins les enfants d'un même père, et devaient plus tard rentrer en grâce avec lui. D'autres honoraient le plus jeune seulement comme maître des régions supérieures, sans pour cela refuser tout culte à l'aîné, dont ils craignaient la puissance. Mais ceux d'entre les Manichéens qui étaient arrivés au comble de l'impiété renonçaient tout à fait au culte du maître du ciel, et réservés tous leurs hommages pour son frère aîné, qu'ils appelaient Satanaki et le premier-né, et qu'ils reconnaissaient comme le principe du monde végétal et animal, en un mot de tous les corps composés, comme aussi de toute corruption et de toute dissolution. Le sabbat considéré comme la cour du démon. Temps, lieu et fréquence de ces assemblées. Métamorphoses qui s'y opèrent. Les crapauds du sabbat. Visions de Dominique, d'un moine de Clairvaux. Des formes que prennent les démons.

L'instinct vital, avons-nous dit, est profondément altéré dans ce commerce affreux de l'homme avec le démon. Or la forme sous laquelle cet instinct se manifeste tout d'abord est celle de l'appétit des aliments. Cet appétit tend, de même que tous les autres, vers l'enfer, et cherche à s'y rassasier. Il y a là comme une horrible contrefaçon du sacrement de l'Eucharistie. De même que celle-ci établit entre Dieu et l'homme une communauté de vie et de sentiment, ainsi l'aliment symbolique dont le démon nourrit ses adeptes forme entre eux et lui des liens intimes et bien difficiles à rompre. Il se fait dans l'homme admis à ces horribles festins comme une sorte de transsubstantiation, qui change pour ainsi dire sa nature en celle du principe auquel il a soumis sa vie, et qui lui en communique à la fois l'esprit, les sentiments et les pensées. Si nous écoutons les témoignages des initiés à ce sujet, ils nous parlent de festins splendides, de tables chargées des mets les plus riches et les plus succulents, couvertes de nappes tissues d'or, de vins précieux servis dans des coupes d'or et d'argent. Ils sont assis à des tables selon leur condition et leur rang. Mais il est remarquable que le sel n'y paraît point, et qu'à la place du pain on n'y voit que des gâteaux faits avec des pois. critical_analysis.relevance: This volume is highly relevant for understanding the historical, theological, and societal context of demonology and witchcraft beliefs in Europe. It provides a comprehensive, albeit 19th-century, perspective on how diabolical magic was conceptualized, practiced (or believed to be practiced), and prosecuted. It highlights the interplay between religious doctrine (Manichaeism, Christian demonology), cultural beliefs (pagan survivals, Romani influence), psychological phenomena (hysteria, somnambulism), and legal systems (Inquisition, secular courts) in shaping the understanding of magic and possession. The detailed case studies offer rich primary source material for researchers in the history of religion, occultism, and social history, demonstrating the complexity and often tragic consequences of these beliefs.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Academic researchers, historians of religion, scholars of Western Esotericism and Occultism, legal historians, cultural anthropologists, and psychologists of religion interested in the historical understanding and societal impact of demonology, witchcraft, and related mystical phenomena. It is also of interest to practitioners seeking to understand the historical roots and philosophical underpinnings of diabolical magic, albeit as a historical study rather than a practical guide for emulation.
